name_origin.etymology: The name derives directly from the Arabic trilateral root D-F-N (د ف ن), meaning 'to bury' or 'to inter'. In the context of North African Jewish cuisine, this refers to the historical cooking method where the pot was hermetically sealed and 'buried' in the embers of the communal oven (ferran) or a charcoal pit on Friday afternoon to cook slowly overnight for Shabbat lunch. In Tunisian and Djerban Judeo-Arabic dialects, the initial 'D' often hardens to a 'T', shifting 'Dafina' to 'Tfina' or 'Tafina'.
name_origin.sources_notes: This etymology is universally accepted in Judeo-Arabic linguistics and culinary history. It parallels the Spanish/Ladino 'Adafina'. The pronunciation 'Tfina' is specific to the Tunisian/Libyan region, whereas 'Dafina' is more common in Morocco.

alternative_names.name: Dafina
alternative_names.notes: The standard Judeo-Arabic term used across the Maghreb, particularly in Morocco.

alternative_names.name: Skhina
alternative_names.notes: Literally meaning 'the hot one' (from Arabic 'sakhun'), used as a euphemism in Morocco to avoid saying the word 'Dafina' which can also imply a burial of the dead.

alternative_names.name: Hamin
alternative_names.notes: The generic Hebrew term for overnight Shabbat stews, derived from the word for 'hot'.

alternative_names.name: Adafina
alternative_names.notes: The medieval Sephardic predecessor to the North African stew.

similar_dishes.name: Cholent
similar_dishes.similarity: Slow-cooked overnight stew with meat, potatoes, and grains (barley/beans) for Shabbat.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Uses beans and Ashkenazi flavor profile (paprika, pepper) rather than the caramelized sugar and North African spices found in Djerban Tfina.

similar_dishes.name: Hrisa / Harissa
similar_dishes.similarity: A wheat or barley-based porridge or stew.
similar_dishes.key_difference: While 'Hrisa' refers to the grain consistency, 'Tfina' specifically implies the overnight Shabbat cooking method. The Djerban Tfina described is essentially a slow-cooked Hrisa with meat.

similar_dishes.name: Tbit
similar_dishes.similarity: Slow-cooked Shabbat dish involving grains (rice) and meat (chicken).
similar_dishes.key_difference: Uses rice and chicken skin stuffing rather than barley and beef.

similar_dishes.name: Cocido Madrileño
similar_dishes.similarity: A chickpea and meat stew derived from the Jewish Adafina/Dafina tradition after the Inquisition.
similar_dishes.key_difference: Contains pork and is not cooked overnight.
